subject: Re: [junit] Parameterized test case pattern (+ a note on JUnit 4)
msgSnippet: I finally figured out the magic piece I was missing. One also has to pass the name of the test method (not the class but the method) to the superclass
messageBody:
I finally figured out the magic piece I was missing. One also has to pass
the name of the test method (not the class but the method) to the
superclass constructor like so:

public DataDrivenTest(int i) {
super("testFoo");
this.i = i;
}

I had to dig into the JUnit source code to debug this.

This taught me something about the code base that may be worth addressing
for JUnit 4. JUnit appears to use regular JUnit assert and fail methods to
check preconditions on its own methods. For example,

protected void runTest() throws Throwable {
assertNotNull(fName);
Method runMethod= null;
try {
// use getMethod to get all public inherited
// methods. getDeclaredMethods returns all
// methods of this class but excludes the
// inherited ones.
runMethod= getClass().getMethod(fName, null);
} catch (NoSuchMethodException e) {
fail("Method \""+fName+"\" not found");
}
if (!Modifier.isPublic(runMethod.getModifiers())) {
fail("Method \""+fName+"\" should be public");
}


The problem with this is that when the precondition does fail, it looks a
lot like a regular test failure. I think JUnit should be refactored not to
do this. assertFOO and fail should be reserved for test cases alone. For
example this code could easily be written as

protected void runTest() throws Throwable {
if (fName == null) {
throw new NullPointerException("Method name was null");
}
Method runMethod= null;
try {
// use getMethod to get all public inherited
// methods. getDeclaredMethods returns all
// methods of this class but excludes the
// inherited ones.
runMethod= getClass().getMethod(fName, null);
} catch (NoSuchMethodException e) {
throw e;
}
if (!Modifier.isPublic(runMethod.getModifiers())) {
fail("Method \""+fName+"\" should be public");
}

I think if I'd gotten NullPointerExceptions and NoSuchMethodExceptions
instead of the AssertionFailedErrors I did get, then I would have figured
this problem out days ago.
